original: Bhagavā etadavoca:

translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyuñjeyya dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ.
analyzed: na kāma sukham anuyuñjeyya hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita na ca atta kilamatha anuyogam anuyuñjeyya dukkham anariyam anattha sahita
translated: “One should not pursue sensual pleasure, which is low, vulgar, coarse, ignoble, and unbeneficial; nor should one pursue self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial.

original: Ete kho, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ete kho bhikkhave ubho ante an upagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhu karaṇī ñāṇa karaṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattati
translated: Without veering towards either of these extremes, the middle way discovered by the Buddha gives rise to vision, gives rise to knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbāna.

original: Ussādanañca jaññā, apasādanañca jaññā;
analyzed: ussādanañca jaññā apasādanañca jaññā
translated: You should know what is contemptible and what is not contemptible.

original: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā nevussādeyya, na apasādeyya, dhammameva deseyya.🔽Sukhavinicchayaṁ jaññā;
analyzed: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā na iva ussādeyya na apasādeyya dhammam eva deseyya  sukha vinicchayam jaññā
translated: Knowing what is contemptible and what is not contemptible, you should neither despise anyone nor be contemptuous. You should teach only the Dhamma.🔽You should know the discernment of happiness.

original: sukhavinicchayaṁ ñatvā ajjhattaṁ sukhamanuyuñjeyya.🔽Rahovādaṁ na bhāseyya, sammukhā na khīṇaṁ bhaṇe.🔽Ataramānova bhāseyya, no taramāno.
analyzed: sukha vinicchayam ñatvā ajjhattam sukham anuyuñjeyya  rahovādam na bhāseyya sammukhā na khīṇam bhaṇe  a taramānaḥ iva bhāseyya na u taramānaḥ
translated: Knowing the discernment of happiness, you should apply yourself to internal happiness.🔽You should not speak in private, and you should not speak what is harmful in public.🔽You should speak without being in a hurry, not in a hurry.

original: Janapadaniruttiṁ nābhiniveseyya, samaññaṁ nātidhāveyyāti—
analyzed: janapada niruttim na abhiniveseyya samaññam na atidhāveyya ati
translated: You should not insist on the vernacular, and you should not go against the conventions of language.

original: ayamuddeso araṇavibhaṅgassa.
analyzed: ayam uddesaḥ araṇa vibhaṅgassa
translated: This is the summary of the analysis of dispassion.

original: ‘Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyuñjeyya dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitan’ti—
analyzed: na kāma sukham anuyuñjeyya hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita na ca atta kilamatha anuyogam anuyuñjeyya dukkham anariyam anattha sahitanti
translated: ‘One should not pursue sensual pleasure based on sensual desire—base, vulgar, common, ignoble, unbeneficial; nor should one pursue self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ; Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?🔽Yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; micchāpaṭipadā.
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta  yaḥ kāma paṭisandhi sukhinaḥ somanassa anuyogaḥ hīnaḥ gammaḥ pothujjanikaḥ anariyaḥ anattha sahitaḥ sa dukkhaḥ eso dhammo sa upaghātaḥ sa upāyāsaḥ sa pariḷāhaḥ micchā paṭipadā
translated: And this is the reason why it was said:🔽The pursuit of the pleasure in sense pleasures is low, vulgar, the way of worldlings, ignoble, unbeneficial, and it is the way of dukkha.

original: Yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyogo hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; sammāpaṭipadā.🔽Yo attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; micchāpaṭipadā.
analyzed: yaḥ kāma paṭisandhi sukhinaḥ somanassa anuyogam an anuyogaḥ hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita adukkhaḥ esaḥ dhammaḥ an upaghātaḥ an upāyāsaḥ a pariḷāhaḥ sammā paṭipadā  yaḥ atta kilamatha anuyogaḥ dukkhaḥ anariyaḥ anattha sahitaḥ sa dukkhaḥ eso dhammo sa upaghātaḥ sa upāyāsaḥ sa pariḷāhaḥ micchā paṭipadā
translated: The non-pursuit of the pleasure in sense pleasures is noble, not the way of worldlings, ignoble, beneficial, and it is the way of sukha.🔽The pursuit of self-mortification is painful, ignoble, unbeneficial, and it is the way of dukkha.

original: Yo attakilamathānuyogaṁ ananuyogo dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; sammāpaṭipadā.
analyzed: yaḥ atta kilamatha anuyogam an anuyogaḥ dukkham anariyam anattha sahita adukkhaḥ esaḥ dhammaḥ an upaghātaḥ an upāyāsaḥ a pariḷāhaḥ sammā paṭipadā
translated: The non-pursuit of self-mortification is not painful, noble, beneficial, and it is the way of sukha.

original: ‘Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogaṁ anuyuñjeyya dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitan’ti—
analyzed: na kāma sukham anuyuñjeyya hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita na ca atta kilamatha anuyogam anuyuñjeyya dukkham anariyam anattha sahitanti
translated: ‘One should not pursue sensual pleasure, which is low, vulgar, coarse, ignoble, and unbeneficial; nor should one pursue self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: This is the reason why this was said.

original: ‘Ete kho ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattatī’ti—
analyzed: ete kho ubho ante an upagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhu karaṇī ñāṇa karaṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattati iti
translated: ‘Avoiding both of these extremes, the Tathagata has awakened to the middle way, which gives rise to vision, which gives rise to knowledge, which leads to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbana.

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?🔽Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta  ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo
translated: This is the reason why this was said.

original: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi sammā saṅkappo sammā vācā sammā kammanto sammā ājīvaḥ sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sati sammā samādhi
translated: It is this noble eightfold path, that is, right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.

original: ‘Ete kho ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattatī’ti—
analyzed: ete kho ubho ante an upagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhu karaṇī ñāṇa karaṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattati iti
translated: ‘Without veering towards either of these two extremes, the middle way rightly taught by the Tathagata produces vision, produces knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbāna.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: This is the meaning of what the Blessed One said in ‘Brief Specifications’, so I have heard.

original: ‘Ussādanañca jaññā, apasādanañca jaññā;
analyzed: ussādanañca jaññā apasādanañca jaññā
translated: ‘You should know what is contemptible and what is not contemptible.

original: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā nevussādeyya, na apasādeyya, dhammameva deseyyā’ti—
analyzed: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā na iva ussādeyya na apasādeyya dhammam eva deseyya ati
translated: Knowing what is contemptible and what is not contemptible, you should neither despise anyone nor be contemptuous. You should teach only the Dhamma.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was said. And in reference to what was it said?

analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave ussādanā ca hoti apasādanā ca no ca dhamma desanā
translated: And how is there contempt and disparagement, but not teaching of the Dhamma?

original: ‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ anuyuttā hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
analyzed: ye kāma paṭisandhi sukhino somanassa anuyogam anuyuttāḥ hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita sabbe te sa dukkhā sa upaghātā sa upāyāsā sa pariḷāhā micchā paṭipannā ati
translated: ‘Those who are devoted to pleasure, who are greedy for pleasure, slaves of their craving for pleasure, will experience pain, distress, and despair in the future. They are on the wrong path. They have gone off in the wrong direction. They have adopted a bad course. They are practicing badly.’

original: iti vadaṁ ittheke apasādeti.
analyzed: iti vadam itthā ike apasāda iti
translated: Thus, in saying this, one disparages some.

original: ‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyuttā hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
analyzed: ye kāma paṭisandhi sukhino somanassa anuyogam an anuyuttāḥ hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita sabbe te adukkhāḥ an upaghātāḥ an upāyāsāḥ a pariḷāhāḥ sammā paṭipannāḥ ti
translated: ‘Those who are not devoted to the pleasure of sensual desires and to delight and association with them, who are not devoted to the practice of self-mortification that is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial, all of them are free from suffering, vexation, despair, and fever, and they practice the right way.’

original: iti vadaṁ ittheke ussādeti.

translated: In saying this, he would encourage some and disparage others.

original: ‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṁ ananuyuttā dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—

translated: ‘Those who don’t practice self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial, are all happy, comfortable, free from trouble and distress, and practicing the right path.’

original: na evamāha.
analyzed: na evam āha
translated: He doesn’t say that.

original: ‘Ananuyogo ca kho adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
analyzed: ananuyogaḥ ca kho adukkhaḥ esaḥ dhammaḥ an upaghātaḥ an upāyāsaḥ a pariḷāhaḥ
translated: ‘Not practicing self-mortification is a teaching that’s free from trouble and distress, free from trouble and distress, and free from trouble and distress.

original: sammāpaṭipadā’ti—
analyzed: sammā paṭipadā ti
translated: It’s the right way.’

original: iti vadaṁ dhammameva deseti.
analyzed: iti vadam dhammam eva deseti
translated: When he says this, he teaches only the Teaching.

original: ‘Yesaṁ kesañci bhavasaṁyojanaṁ appahīnaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
analyzed: yesam kesañci bhava sayojanam sabbe te sa dukkhā sa upaghātā sa upāyāsā sa pariḷāhā micchā paṭipannā ati
translated: ‘Those who haven’t given up the fetter of existence are all miserable, with trouble and distress, with anguish and fever, and they practice the wrong way.’

original: na evamāha.
analyzed: na evam āha
translated: He doesn’t say that.

original: ‘Bhavasaṁyojane ca kho appahīne bhavopi appahīno hotī’ti—
analyzed: bhava sayojane ca kho appahīne bhavaḥ api appahīnaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘When the fetter of existence hasn’t been given up, existence hasn’t been given up.’

original: iti vadaṁ dhammameva deseti.
analyzed: iti vadam dhammam eva deseti
translated: When he says this, he teaches only the Teaching.

original: ‘Yesaṁ kesañci bhavasaṁyojanaṁ pahīnaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
analyzed: yesam kesañci bhava sayojanam sabbe te adukkhāḥ an upaghātāḥ an upāyāsāḥ a pariḷāhāḥ sammā paṭipannāḥ ati
translated: ‘Those who have given up the fetter of existence are all happy, comfortable, free from trouble and distress, and practicing the right path.’

original: na evamāha.
analyzed: na evam āha
translated: He doesn’t say that.

original: ‘Bhavasaṁyojane ca kho pahīne bhavopi pahīno hotī’ti—
analyzed: bhava sayojane ca khalu pahīne bhavaḥ api pahīnaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘When the fetter of existence has been given up, existence has been given up.’

original: iti vadaṁ dhammameva deseti.
analyzed: iti vadam dhammam eva deseti
translated: When he says this, he teaches only the Teaching.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, nevussādanā hoti na apasādanā, dhammadesanā ca.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave na iva ussādanā hoti na apasādanā dhamma desanā ca
translated: That’s how there’s neither belittling nor praising, but teaching the Dhamma.

original: ‘Ussādanañca jaññā, apasādanañca jaññā;
analyzed: ussādanañca jaññā apasādanañca jaññā
translated: ‘You should know belittling and praising.

original: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā nevussādeyya, na apasādeyya, dhammameva deseyyā’ti—
analyzed: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā na iva ussādeyya na apasādeyya dhammam eva deseyya ati
translated: Knowing belittling and praising, you shouldn’t belittle or praise, but teach the Dhamma.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

original: ‘Sukhavinicchayaṁ jaññā;
analyzed: sukha vinicchayam jaññā
translated: ‘You should know the discernment of pleasure.

original: sukhavinicchayaṁ ñatvā ajjhattaṁ sukhamanuyuñjeyyā’ti—
analyzed: sukha vinicchayam ñatvā ajjhattam sukham anuyuñjeyyāti
translated: Knowing the discernment of pleasure, you should be intent on pleasure internally.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was said. And this is why it was said.

original: Pañcime, bhikkhave, kāmaguṇā.
analyzed: pañcime bhikkhave kāma guṇāḥ
translated: There are these five kinds of pleasure and joy based on worldly states.

original: Katame pañca?
analyzed: katame pañca
translated: What five?

original: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,🔽sotaviññeyyā saddā …
analyzed: cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā  sota viññeyyā saddā
translated: Visual objects cognizable by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.🔽Sounds cognizable by the ear …

original: ghānaviññeyyā gandhā …
analyzed: ghāna viññeyyāḥ gandhāḥ
translated: Smells cognizable by the nose …

original: jivhāviññeyyā rasā …
analyzed: jivhā viññeyyāḥ rasāḥ
translated: Tastes cognizable by the tongue …

original: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
analyzed: kāya viññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā
translated: Tactile objects cognizable by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

original: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca kāmaguṇā.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave pañca kāmaguṇā
translated: These are the five kinds of pleasure and joy based on worldly states.

original: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ idaṁ vuccati kāmasukhaṁ mīḷhasukhaṁ puthujjanasukhaṁ anariyasukhaṁ.
analyzed: yam kho bhikkhave ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukham somanassam idam vuccati kāma sukham mīḍha sukham puthujjana sukham anariya sukha
translated: The pleasure and joy that arise in dependence on these five cords of sensual pleasure are called sensual pleasure, a filthy pleasure, a coarse pleasure, an ignoble pleasure.

original: ‘Na āsevitabbaṁ, na bhāvetabbaṁ, na bahulīkātabbaṁ, bhāyitabbaṁ etassa sukhassā’ti—vadāmi.
analyzed: na āsevitabba na bhāvetabba na bahulīkātabba bhāyitabba etassa sukhassa ativadāmi
translated: I say that this pleasure should not be pursued, developed, or cultivated, and that one should live in such a way that one’s pleasure is not dependent on it.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati  vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati  pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati pe tatiyam jhānam pe
translated: Here, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.🔽With the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhana, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the fading away as well of rapture, he abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana, on account of which noble ones announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.’🔽With the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, he enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: Idaṁ vuccati nekkhammasukhaṁ pavivekasukhaṁ upasamasukhaṁ sambodhisukhaṁ.
analyzed: idam vuccati nekkhamma sukham paviveka sukham upasama sukham sambodhi sukha
translated: This is called the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of enlightenment.

original: ‘Āsevitabbaṁ, bhāvetabbaṁ, bahulīkātabbaṁ, na bhāyitabbaṁ etassa sukhassā’ti—vadāmi.
analyzed: āsevitabba bhāvetabba bahulīkātabba na bhāyitabba etassa sukhassa ativadāmi
translated: ‘It should be cultivated, developed, and made much of, and one should not be afraid of it,’ I say.

original: ‘Sukhavinicchayaṁ jaññā;
analyzed: sukha vinicchayam jaññā
translated: ‘You should know the discernment of bliss.

original: sukhavinicchayaṁ ñatvā ajjhattaṁ sukhamanuyuñjeyyā’ti—
analyzed: sukha vinicchayam ñatvā ajjhattam sukham anuyuñjeyyāti
translated: Having known the discernment of bliss, you should devote yourself to the bliss internally.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘You should know the discernment of bliss.’

original: ‘Rahovādaṁ na bhāseyya, sammukhā na khīṇaṁ bhaṇe’ti—
analyzed: rahovādam na bhāseyya sammukhā na khīṇam bhaṇa iti
translated: ‘You should not speak in secret, and do not speak in public of what is divisive.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta
translated: So it was said.

original: Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: And with reference to what was this said?

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yaṁ jaññā rahovādaṁ abhūtaṁ atacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ sasakkaṁ taṁ rahovādaṁ na bhāseyya.🔽Yampi jaññā rahovādaṁ bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ tassapi sikkheyya avacanāya.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave yam jaññā rahovādam a bhūtam a taccham anattha sahitam sa sakkam tam rahovādam na bhāseyya  yam pi jaññā rahovādam bhūtam taccham anattha sahitam tassa api sikkheyya a vacanāya
translated: There is the case where one might know a secret talk to be untrue, incorrect, and unbeneficial. One should not speak of that secret talk.🔽Even if one knows a secret talk to be true and correct, but unbeneficial, one should train in not speaking of that secret talk.

original: Yañca kho jaññā rahovādaṁ bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ tatra kālaññū assa tassa rahovādassa vacanāya.
analyzed: yat ca kho jaññā rahovādam bhūtam attha sahitam tatra kālaññū assa tassa rahovādassa vacanāya
translated: But if one knows a secret talk to be true, correct, and beneficial, one should know the time to speak that secret talk.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yaṁ jaññā sammukhā khīṇavādaṁ abhūtaṁ atacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ sasakkaṁ taṁ sammukhā khīṇavādaṁ na bhāseyya.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave yam jaññā sammukhā khīṇa vādam a bhūtam a taccham anattha sahitam sa sakkam tam sammukhā khīṇa vādam na bhāseyya
translated: “If you know that a criticism made in the presence of someone is untrue, incorrect, and unbeneficial, then you should not repeat it, even in part.

original: Yampi jaññā sammukhā khīṇavādaṁ bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ tassapi sikkheyya avacanāya.
analyzed: yam pi jaññā sammukhā khīṇa vādam bhūtam taccham anattha sahitam tassa api sikkheyya avacanāya
translated: If you know that a criticism made in the presence of someone is true, correct, but unbeneficial, then you should train yourself to not repeat it.

original: Yañca kho jaññā sammukhā khīṇavādaṁ bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ tatra kālaññū assa tassa sammukhā khīṇavādassa vacanāya.
analyzed: yat ca kho jaññā sammukhā khīṇa vādam bhūtam tat śam attha sahitam tatra kālaññū assa tassa sammukhā khīṇa vādassa vacanāya
translated: If you know that a criticism made in the presence of someone is true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the time to repeat it.

original: ‘Rahovādaṁ na bhāseyya, sammukhā na khīṇaṁ bhaṇe’ti—
analyzed: rahovādam na bhāseyya sammukhā na khīṇam bhaṇa iti
translated: ‘Don’t speak in private, and don’t repeat in public what has been said in private.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

original: ‘Ataramānova bhāseyya no taramāno’ti—
analyzed: a taramānā iva bhāseyya na u taramānā uti
translated: ‘Speak without being hurried, not in a hurry.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, taramānassa bhāsato kāyopi kilamati, cittampi upahaññati, saropi upahaññati, kaṇṭhopi āturīyati, avisaṭṭhampi hoti aviññeyyaṁ taramānassa bhāsitaṁ.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave taramānassa bhāsato kāyaḥ api kilamati cittam api upahaññati saraḥ api upahaññati kaṇṭhaḥ api āturīyati avisaṭṭham pi hoti aviññeyyam taramānassa bhāsita
translated: “If you speak in a hurry, your body, mind, and speech are harmed. Your speech is unclear and incomprehensible.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ataramānassa bhāsato kāyopi na kilamati, cittampi na upahaññati, saropi na upahaññati, kaṇṭhopi na āturīyati, visaṭṭhampi hoti viññeyyaṁ ataramānassa bhāsitaṁ.
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave a taramānassa bhāsato kāyaḥ api na kilamati cittam api na upahaññati saraḥ api na upahaññati kaṇṭhaḥ api na āturīyati visaṭṭham pi hoti viññeyyam a taramānassa bhāsita
translated: When speaking without hurry, the body doesn’t get tired, the mind doesn’t get overwhelmed, the voice doesn’t get overwhelmed, the throat doesn’t get hoarse, and what is spoken without hurry is easily understood.

original: ‘Ataramānova bhāseyya, no taramāno’ti—
analyzed: a taramānā iva bhāseyya na u taramānā uti
translated: ‘Speak without hurry, not hurriedly.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: This is the reason why this was said.

original: ‘Janapadaniruttiṁ nābhiniveseyya, samaññaṁ nātidhāveyyā’ti—
analyzed: janapada niruttim na abhiniveseyya samaññam na atidhāveyya ati
translated: ‘Don’t insist on the local language and don’t override the common usage.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was said. And this is why it was said.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca abhiniveso hoti samaññāya ca atisāro?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave janapada niruttiyā ca abhinivesaḥ hoti samaññāya ca atisāro
translated: And how does one insist on the local language and override the common usage?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, tadevekaccesu janapadesu ‘pātī’ti sañjānanti, ‘pattan’ti sañjānanti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave tat eva ekaccesu janapadesu pāti iti sañjānanti pattanti sañjānanti
translated: In some countries they call a plate ‘pātī’, in some ‘pattan’,

original: ‘vittan’ti sañjānanti, ‘sarāvan’ti sañjānanti ‘dhāropan’ti sañjānanti, ‘poṇan’ti
analyzed: vittanti sañjānanti sarāvanti sañjānanti dhāropanti sañjānanti poṇanti
translated: in some ‘vittan’, in some ‘sarāva’, in some ‘dhāropan’, in some ‘poṇa’,

original: sañjānanti, ‘pisīlavan’ti sañjānanti.
analyzed: sañjānanti pisīlavanti sañjānanti
translated: in some ‘pisīlavan’.

original: Iti yathā yathā naṁ tesu tesu janapadesu sañjānanti tathā tathā thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharati:
analyzed: iti yathā yathā nam tesu tesu janapadesu sañjānanti tathā tathā thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharati
translated: So he speaks obstinately and dogmatically, insisting:

original: ‘idameva saccaṁ, moghamaññan’ti.
analyzed: idam eva sat ca mogham aññanti
translated: ‘This alone is the truth, other ideas are silly!’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca abhiniveso hoti samaññāya ca atisāro.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave janapada niruttiyā ca abhinivesaḥ hoti samaññāya ca atisāro
translated: That is how there is insistence on the local language and disdain for the spoken language.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca anabhiniveso hoti samaññāya ca anatisāro?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave janapada niruttiyā ca an abhinivesaḥ hoti samaññāya ca an atisāro
translated: And how is there no insistence on the local language and no disdain for the spoken language?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, tadevekaccesu janapadesu ‘pātī’ti sañjānanti, ‘pattan’ti sañjānanti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave tat eva ekaccesu janapadesu pāti iti sañjānanti pattanti sañjānanti
translated: In some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘pātī’, in some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘pattan’,

original: ‘vittan’ti sañjānanti, ‘sarāvan’ti sañjānanti, ‘dhāropan’ti sañjānanti, ‘poṇan’ti
analyzed: vittanti sañjānanti sarāvanti sañjānanti dhāropanti sañjānanti poṇanti
translated: in some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘vitta’, in some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘sarāva’, in some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘dhāropana’, in some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘poṇa’,

original: sañjānanti, ‘pisīlavan’ti sañjānanti.
analyzed: sañjānanti pisīlavanti sañjānanti
translated: in some countries they call a ‘bowl’ a ‘pisīlava’.🔽So he speaks without obstinacy and without dogmatism, thinking:

original: Iti yathā yathā naṁ tesu tesu janapadesu sañjānanti ‘idaṁ kira me āyasmanto sandhāya voharantī’ti tathā tathā voharati aparāmasaṁ.
analyzed: iti yathā yathā nam tesu tesu janapadesu sañjānanti idam kira me āyasmantaḥ sandhāya voharanti iti tathā tathā voharati aparāmasa
translated: ‘The venerable ones speak referring to this.’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca anabhiniveso hoti, samaññāya ca anatisāro.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave janapada niruttiyā ca anabhinivesaḥ hoti samaññāya ca anatisāro
translated: That is how there is no insistence on local language and no disparaging of standard language.

original: ‘Janapadaniruttiṁ nābhiniveseyya samaññaṁ nātidhāveyyā’ti—
analyzed: janapada niruttim na abhiniveseyya samaññam na atidhāveyya ati
translated: ‘Don’t insist on local language and don’t disparage standard language.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vutta idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: This is the reason why this was said.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave yaḥ kāma paṭisandhi sukhinaḥ somanassa anuyogaḥ hīnaḥ gammaḥ pothujjanikaḥ anariyaḥ anattha sahitaḥ sa dukkhaḥ eso dhammo sa upaghātaḥ sa upāyāsaḥ sa pariḷāho
translated: “There is the pursuit of the pleasure of forms cognizable by the eye—low, vulgar, common, ignoble, unbeneficial, and resulting in suffering. This is a practice that is painful now and ripens in the future as pain.

original: micchāpaṭipadā.
analyzed: micchā paṭipadā
translated: This is the wrong way.

original: Tasmā eso dhammo saraṇo.
analyzed: tasmai esaḥ dhammaḥ saraṇaḥ
translated: That is why this practice is stressful.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyogo hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave yaḥ kāma paṭisandhi sukhinaḥ somanassa anuyogam an anuyogaḥ hīnam gammam pothujjanikam anariyam anattha sahita adukkhaḥ esaḥ dhammaḥ an upaghātaḥ an upāyāsaḥ a pariḷāhaḥ
translated: “There is the non-pursuit of the pleasure of forms cognizable by the eye—low, vulgar, common, ignoble, unbeneficial, and resulting in suffering. This is a practice that is pleasant now and ripens in the future as pleasure.

original: sammāpaṭipadā.
analyzed: sammā paṭipadā
translated: This is the right way.

original: Tasmā eso dhammo araṇo.
